headline: What's News: Business & Finance

headline: Treasury to Sell $57 Billion of Bills on Monday
summary: The Treasury Department plans to sell $57 billion in short-term bills on Monday, divided between $29 billion of 13-week bills and $28 billion of 26-week bills.

headline: San Francisco Gets 2013 America's Cup
summary: Organizers of the America's Cup sailing regatta announced plans to hold the 2013 race in San Francisco, allowing billionaire Larry Ellison to defend the cup in the waters near his home.

headline: Asian Shares End Year Mixed
summary: Asian markets ended mixed in light trading Friday, with Chinese stocks posting solid gains led by coal producers. Shanghai ended the day up 1.8%.

headline: Treasurys Gain 5.51% in 2010
summary: U.S. government debt posted gains of 5.51% for 2010, according to Barclays index data. TIPS, or Treasury inflation protected securities, chalked chalk up gains of 5.84% for the year. The 10-year yield ended 2010 at 3.290%, down from 3.837% a year ago.

headline: Oil Prices Advanced 15.1% in 2010
summary: Crude-oil futures settled at $91.38 a barrel on the last day of 2010, charting a course toward $100 and beyond in the new year.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading for the week ended Dec 24, 2010

headline: Banner Year for Corn, Soybeans
summary: U.S. soybean and corn futures ended the year at more than two-year highs, closing a strong 2010 for agricultural commodities.

headline: European Stocks End With a Fall
summary: European stock markets ended a generally solid year on a down note. The FTSE 100 gained 9% for the year. Autos were the year's hottest sector, while BP's losses helped make the oil and gas sector the biggest laggard.

headline: Qiao Xing Mobile Communication, Fuwei Films (Holdings): Biggest Price Decliners (QXM, FFHL)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Heard & Scene Photos of the Year
summary: From galas to benefits, celebrities to performance artists, here's a look at some of the year's best Heard & Scene photos.

headline: Billy the Kid Fails to Win Pardon
summary: The iconic outlaw Billy the Kid will not receive a posthumous pardon after all, New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson announced Friday, his last day in office.

headline: New York Sports Photos of the Year
summary: Some of the year's best New York sports photos include a soggy start to the U.S. Open in Flushing, race competitors scaling a greasy wall in Brooklyn and a double dutch team performing in Harlem.

headline: A 2010 Stew: Oil Spill, Potash, iPads
summary: It was a year when a well blowout kept pouring oil into the Gulf of Mexico, the housing market kept slumping and a corporate scandal kept a Silicon Valley CEO in the headlines. But 2010 also saw the economy perk up as consumers bought millions of cars, resumed taking flights and flocked to electronic gadgets such as iPads and smartphones. Take our highly selective quiz about key -- and off-key -- corporate events of 2010.

headline: Hungary to Regulate All Media
summary: Hungary published a controversial media law that will regulate all media directed at or published in Hungary, including Internet news portals and web-based publications.

headline: India, Iran Bank Officials Meet
summary: The Reserve Bank of India said its officials met representatives of Iran's central bank Friday to discuss the issue of payments for imports.

headline: Merkel: Euro Is Basis for Our Prosperity
summary: In a year-end address, German Chancellor Angela Merkel will stress the importance of the euro to Germany despite recent problems, calling the common currency the basis of European prosperity.

headline: State Visits to India in 2010
summary: From the visit of Nepal's President Ram Baran Yadav in February to Russian President Dmitry Medvedev's visit in December, state visits kept Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh busy last year.

headline: The Top India Blogs of 2010
summary: These are snapshots of the most popular posts that appeared on the Wall Street Journal's India Real Time blog in 2010.

headline: Reliance Group Sheds Billionaire's Name
summary: Indian business conglomerate Reliance Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group has renamed itself Reliance Group, dropping the name of billionaire Anil Ambani in a marketing exercise.

headline: China Expands Program for Exporters' Earnings
summary: China will allow the country's exporters to park their revenue overseas, expanding a program that marks a significant loosening of currency controls and could reduce pressure on the yuan to appreciate.

headline: Cameron Sees 'Difficult' Year Ahead
summary: The U.K. government will be "relentlessly focused" on supporting economic growth and job creation in 2011, despite the "heavy lifting" needed to rein in the country's gaping budget deficit, the U.K. prime minister said.

headline: U.K. House Prices Unexpectedly Rise
summary: U.K. house prices posted a surprise monthly increase at the end of 2010,  the Nationwide Building Society said.

headline: China Extends Car Subsidies
summary: China will extend subsidies for energy-efficient cars and new energy cars throughout 2011, as part of China's aim to conserve energy and reduce emissions.

headline: Warning on China, U.S.  Feed Spat
summary: An investigation that China launched into U.S. exports of an animal feed is "surprising and could be disruptive to trade," the U.S. Grains Council said.

headline: India Wheat Output to Top Estimate
summary: India will likely reap more wheat than the government's estimate this crop year despite late sowings indicating that the South Asian nation will have ample supplies of the staple grain to help fight stubbornly high food prices.

headline: India's Best Returns of 2010
summary: From silver outperforming gold returns to the soaring real estate prices in major cities, a look at some of the best investments of 2010, in pictures.

headline: The Best-Performing Investments of 2010
summary: Precious metals earned high returns in India this year but investors should limit their exposure, says Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer.

headline: NALCO to Bid for Power Plants
summary: State-run National Aluminium Co. will bid for two of India's upcoming 4,000 megawatt power plants in the eastern states of Orissa and Chhattisgarh, a senior company executive said.

headline: Bird Flu Found in South Korea
summary: Bird flu was discovered in chickens in South Korea at two farms, prompting an emergency cull and raising concerns the disease might spread to people.

headline: Bookshelf: Stories to Fill a 'Gaping Lack'
summary: Paul Genders reviews "Best European Fiction 2011," edited by Aleksandar Hemon (Dalkey Archive Press).

headline: Belichick Nearly in a Class All by Himself
summary: If his Patriots beat Miami Sunday, it will mark the fourth time in the last eight years that New England has won at least 14 games, making Mr. Belichick the first coach in NFL history with four 14-win seasons. Plus,  Troy University spent $5 million on football while Ohio State spent more than $31 million.

headline: Deep Down in Their Private Lives
summary: Three things are needed to make Edward Albee's "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" work. Chicago's Steppenwolf Theatre Company gets it all just right.

headline: Oprah on 2011 Resolutions: Don't Make Any
summary: Oprah Winfrey has a lot of big goals for the coming year. She is creating a new cable TV network. She is bringing her daytime talk show to an end after 25 years. But there's one thing she isn't doing to guide herself: making any New Year's resolutions.

headline: Hitting the Moguls
summary: The report's author, Tom Fitzpatrick, is taking his own advice. He's out of the office until Jan. 3.

headline: Dead Soul Is a Debt Collector
summary: Martha Kunkle died in 1995. But that didn't stop her signature from appearing on thousands of affidavits submitted by one of the nation's largest debt collectors, Portfolio Recovery Associates.

headline: Bloom Is Off International Funds
summary: International-stock mutual funds trailed their U.S. counterparts in 2010, yet double-digit gains under doubtful conditions was still a welcome surprise for investors.

headline: Money-Market-Fund Assets Increase by $22.39 Billion
summary: Assets in money-market funds rose $22.39 billion in the week ended Wednesday, helping recoup outflows posted in the prior two weeks, as institutional funds posted strong inflows.

headline: AIG Unit Improves Disclosures on Backstops
summary: Chartis, the property-and-casualty insurance unit of AIG, said it has taken steps to improve disclosures about guarantees its subsidiaries provided to other AIG units, after a state regulator found "deficiencies" in its reporting.

headline: Bumpy Climb for Stocks in 2010
summary: Amid stumbles and scares, U.S. stocks clambered to a second straight year of gains, in which the Dow reached levels not seen since the fall of Lehman Brothers in September 2008.

headline: Speaker Says Tax Is No-Go
summary: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said he's "unequivocally" opposed to resurrecting a stock-transfer tax as a way of reducing the state's deficit, rejecting calls by labor leaders to force Wall Street to bail out Albany.

headline: Tycoon's Sentence Is Extended
summary: A Moscow court sentenced former oil tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky to six more years in prison in a case that's widely seen as retribution for the billionaire's efforts to challenge the Kremlin's control.

headline: For Apps, Profit Focus Is Blurry
summary: Companies have launched a slew of photography apps for the iPhone and other smartphones, but many of these start-ups are still trying to figure out the best way to profit from their software programs.

headline: Housing Pain Pits Neighbor Against Neighbor
summary: Among the casualties of the housing storm is the neighborliness of certain communities where residents live close together, some paying mortgages and homeowner-association fees, others not

headline: Crime Numbers Drop in 2010; Violence Spikes
summary: For 2010, New York City is once again on pace to record an annual decrease in major crimes, even as the New York Police Department was placed under unprecedented pressure to justify its crime figures.

headline: Business Watch
summary: Here is a selection of business news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Credit-Card Plan Irks Retailers
summary: The companies are urging the Fed to drop a proposal that would require credit-card issuers to consider only a borrower's "independent" income rather than household income.

headline: In Lisbon, Writers Die but Art Lives On
summary: José Saramago died in June at 87. It's hard not to assume that at least some die-hard fans will save their private memorials for New Year's Eve, which plays a special role in two of his most important books.

headline: Tip of the Day
summary: Bayern Munich began the season as heavy favorite to land a 23rd title in German football, but midway through the campaign the country's most successful club is in unfamiliar territory.

headline: Private Equity's Cosmetic Surgery
summary: As the industry seeks to raise $300 billion in new funds globally next year, investors, in theory, should be able to strike better deals.

headline: Conko and Miller: A Spoonful of Sugar Will Soon Cost More
summary: Environmental lawsuits to obstruct and delay biotech crops will raise food prices in 2011.

headline: At New Salon, Old-School Spirits
summary: Come Mondays in January, Salon Millesime, a vintage French lounge inside the Carlton Hotel, will be offering 'Voix de Ville,' a night of old-school performances.

headline: Stephen Moore: Can Rick Scott Put Florida to Work?
summary: "I'm going to run this state like a business," the new governor says.

headline: Vanguard Set to Acquire Detroit Hospitals
summary: Detroit Medical Center will pay a $30 million fine to the federal government, in a settlement that clears the way for the takeover of the hospital system by Vanguard Health Systems.

headline: J.P. Morgan Chase Sued Over Petters Ponzi
summary: The trustee attempting to recoup money for the companies of convicted Ponzi scheme figure Tom Petters has sued J.P. Morgan Chase, seeking more than $300 million in multiple lawsuits.

headline: The Castle on Skid Row
summary: Antiques collector Gertrude Zachary built her dream house, a Paris-inspired estate, in a derelict part of Albuquerque, N.M., as a showcase for her religious art and stained-glass windows.

headline: Newark's Multicultural River Bend
summary: The storefronts and restaurants of Ferry Street, the commercial artery of Newark's Ironbound district, testify to the many layers of immigration that have washed over this working-class area tucked into a bend in the Passaic River.

headline: For Europe, Better Communication in 2011
summary: Top of the European leaders' new year resolutions: promising to stay on message.

headline: The Gods Return
summary: "All Things Shining," explores the search for dignity and grace in our time, surveying, as the book's subtitle has it, "the western classics to find meaning in a secular age." Eric Ormsby reviews.

headline: Where Does Amar'e Fit?
summary: A natural power forward, the Knicks' Amar'e Stoudemire has excelled so far this season at center.

headline: Drug Approvals Slipped in 2010
summary: The FDA approved about 21 drugs in 2010, a relatively modest figure that shows the pharmaceutical industry hasn't yet escaped its drought in recent years.

headline: Reading Today About Women of Yesterday
summary: Cynthia Crossen on her favorite fierce female characters in historical fiction.

headline: Jobless Claims Hit Lowest Level Since '08
summary: Initial claims for unemployment benefits fell last week to the lowest level in more than two years, offering another hopeful sign that the job market is improving.

headline: Borders Delays Payments
summary: Book retailer Borders Group said it is delaying payments to some publishers, a sign that its financial troubles are worsening. The company said the delays were part of its efforts to refinance its debt.

headline: James Kirchick: WikiLeaks' Collateral Damage
summary: Julian Assange's reckless behavior could cost Zimbabwe's leading democrat his life.

headline: Sri Lanka's Shrinking Payoff
summary: Sri Lanka's postwar economic boom is only just beginning. Have investors already missed the boat?

headline: Foraging Brings Surprises
summary: With the arrival of Nordic cuisine and chefs shedding their kitchen straitjackets, 2010 was a more interesting year than diners could expect, says Bruce Palling.

headline: Magic 112, Knicks 103
summary: Seven Magic players scored in double figures as the home team beat the Knicks in Orlando. Knicks forward Amar'e Stoudemire scored 30 and Wilson Chandler scored 29.

headline: Wedding Can't Mask U.K.'s Grim Outlook
summary: The way things look now the April royal wedding in the House of Windsor might well be the 2011 highwater mark for Britons and their economy.

headline: Solar Plant to Generate Power After Sundown
summary: Abengoa Solar expects to start construction in 2011 on a plant in Arizona that will store sun-generated heat to provide six extra hours a day of electric-generating capacity.

headline: Ski-In, Ski-Out
summary: Luxury homes in Montana, Utah, and Colorado.

headline: Maliki's Mistake
summary: A continued American troop presence is good for Iraq, and the combustible Persian Gulf region.

headline: From Birth to Death, the Year in Sports
summary: It's tempting to dismiss this year in New York sports as nothing more than a debacle. But when we looked more closely, we realized the year of our pro sports teams could be compressed into the entire life cycle of a human being.

headline: Swinging Farewell to 2010
summary: Ring in the New Year with Dr. Lonnie Smith, Vince Giordano and the Bad Plus this week.

headline: A Ball With Belles and Whistles
summary: The 56th-anniversary edition of the International Debutante Ball featured 28 young women who wore puffy white gowns and persuaded their families to shell out a required $14,000 on tables.

headline: Energy Pulses Through Houseago's Sculpture
summary: Leeds-born, Los Angeles-resident artist Thomas Houseago's work is vigorous, sometimes brutal, because it displays the method of its making.

headline: Burlesque Is Back in Paris
summary: The stars of Mathieu Amalric's film "Tournee" have opened their bubbly, bawdy "Cabaret New Burlesque" for a three-week run.

headline: A Do-Over, Anyone?
summary: For the Mets and Wall Street Journal beat reporter Mike Sielski, hindsight is 20-20.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Big Health-Care Changes Arrive in 2011
summary: New taxes on drug makers, lower prescription-drug costs for seniors and restrictions on tax-free medical spending accounts are among a slate of health-law provisions that kick in Saturday.

headline: Anne Hendershott: Catholic Hospitals vs. the Bishops
summary: Administrators shop for theologians to support practices that conflict with church teachings.

headline: Andy Borowitz's Resolutions for 2011
summary: He doesn't make them for himself, but he does offer them to others. For 2011, he wants you to make a real effort to employ fake politeness in your emails.

headline: Pete Irvine Avoids the Street Buzz
summary: The organizer of Edinburgh's New Year's Eve Party talks to The Wall Street Journal Europe about how he starts his weekend.

headline: U.S. Mortgage Rates Mostly Rise
summary: Mortgage rates rose in the past week, following Treasury yields higher.

headline: What Are They Feeding the Badgers?
summary: Wisconsin football has capitalized on the state's endless supply of beefy linemen.

headline: Striking a Chord With Music Fans
summary: Andreas Waldburg-Wolfegg wants to help expand a musical nonprofit that he says blasts away traditional musical genres. The Chicago investment fund manager is giving $180,000 to the International Contemporary Ensemble, a new-age ensemble of 33 young musicians based in Brooklyn and Chicago.

headline: Subway Cellist Brings Music to the Masses
summary: Cellist Dale Henderson wants more people to experience Bach's music, so he is bringing it to them one platform at a time.

headline: Bumper Prizes for Deep Pockets
summary: Auction-house executives appeared almost puzzled by the buoyant mood of collectors as buyers dug deep in what was supposed to be a tough year.

headline: Giants Need Vintage Play From Offensive Line
summary: The 9-6 Giants must win this Sunday's game at Washington to keep their playoff hopes alive. To do that, they'll have to run the ball, and that starts with dominant play from the guys up front.

headline: As Euphoria Abounds, Some Warning Signs
summary: Maybe it's just the eggnog talking, but Wall Street has given itself over to a glass-overflowing mentality.

headline: Criticism of Bloomberg Mounts
summary: Mayor Bloomberg said his administration fulfilled a promise to plow every city street, but elected officials and others insisted some streets never saw a plow before the 7 a.m. deadline.

headline: The Road Into the Open
summary: Arto Paasilinna's "The Year of the Hare," is the best-selling allegory about a journalist who abandons his city life for the companionship of a pet hare. Pico Iyer reviews.

headline: Let's Postpone Tax Day
summary: One of out three taxpayers will have to wait. Thanks, Congress.

headline: Developing Countries Keep Buying Dollars
summary: Central banks in developing countries increased their purchases of U.S. dollars and pared their euro holdings in the third quarter.

headline: Jon Picoult: Check With My Chief of Staff
summary: Corporate executives want to sound presidential. In fact, they're tone deaf.

headline: Texas Challenges EPA Again
summary: Texas filed a lawsuit that challenges the Obama administration's ability to take over the state's air permitting program.

headline: BCS Behemoths Battle the Little Guys
summary: In college football's postseason, there's a perception that big-names like Georgia play poorly against lesser-knowns like Central Florida because they lack motivation. Here's the reality: The big dogs do just fine.

headline: Trash Overhaul Stalls in Toledo
summary: Toledo's efforts to deploy a high-tech garbage-collection system appeared headed for the junk yard, as residents complain about service problems and the city grapples with unanticipated expenses.

headline: Drinking Now
summary: Mathieu Barret is a young winemaker who not only farms his estate organically but, keen to experiment, is also moving into biodynamics.

headline: 'Spider-Man' Confirms Actress to Leave
summary: Natalie Mendoza, a leading actress of "Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark" has left the production, the show's lead producer confirmed Thursday.

headline: Europe's Flabby Takeover Rules
summary: The way Spanish construction group Actividades de Construccion y Servicios's bid for German rival Hochtief has played out illustrates how far Europe has to go in creating an efficiently harmonized takeover process.

headline: Icy Airline Investors Shrug Off Blizzard
summary: Despite a giant U.S. snowstorm and the impact of the more-severe disruption caused by volcanic ash in the spring, airline stocks have hardly suffered.

headline: Val Kilmer Relists Ranch
summary: Actor Val Kilmer has re-listed his 6,000 acre New Mexico ranch for $18.5 million. Plus, Jonathan Adler and Simon Doonan reduce the price of their home on Shelter Island, and Harry Hagey, the former Dodge & Cox CEO, buys ranches in Sun Valley.

headline: 2011 Euro-Zone Outlook
summary: The euro-zone economy is expected to expand mildly through 2011, aided by a recovery in global demand. But forecasts are overshadowed by the government debt crisis. See how member nations stack up.

headline: Johnson Controls in Big Parts Deal
summary: Germany's Keiper Recaro said it plans to sell the bulk of its auto-parts business to Johnson Controls and focus on the growing market in seats for commercial aircraft.

headline: States Try to Force Mortgage Workouts
summary: A few states are forcing banks to sit down with borrowers facing foreclosure and attempt to hammer out a settlement face to face rather than going to court.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Dec. 31, 2010

headline: A 2010 Quiz: Oil Spill, Potash and iPads
summary: It was a year when a well blowout kept pouring oil into the Gulf of Mexico, the housing market kept slumping and a corporate scandal kept a Silicon Valley CEO in the headlines.

headline: Contracts Draw Fire Over Ties to Christie
summary: New Jersey Democrats demanded the state cancel hundreds of millions of dollars in state contracts to companies that donated to a pro-Gov. Chris Christie advocacy group.

headline: Venezuela to Devalue Currency
summary: Venezuela will devalue its "strong bolívar" currency on New Year's Day, the second such devaluation within a year and at least the fifth major devaluation during the government of President Chávez.

headline: Orange Win a Thriller
summary: Syracuse tops Kansas State 36-34 in the first Pinstripe Bowl at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Not Your Normal Playoff Scenarios
summary: There is a lot more on the line for contending teams this weekend than their seeding in the NFL playoffs.

headline: The One That Got Away
summary: "Southland," a police drama dropped by NBC after just one season, returns for what promises to be a third season of exceptional writing and superb acting on TNT.

headline: I Love You, 'Blue Valentine'
summary: Starring Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams, the film can be crushing in its portrayal of how two people in love come to lacerate and devastate each other, says Joe Morgenstern.

headline: Estonia Prepares to Adopt the Euro
summary: When the tiny Baltic nation of Estonia rings in the new year, it will become the latest addition to the euro zone—and the poorest member of a currency bloc that is struggling to restore financial stability.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Treasurys Dinged by Data
summary: Most Treasurys were left modestly lower on the last full trading day of 2010 as investors parted with the low-risk instruments after a trio of reports pointed to an improving economy.

headline: A War on Good Taste
summary: There are those who would not only vilify foods considered less than salubrious, but prohibit them. And what a ridiculous spectacle that is, says Eric Felten.

headline: David Feith: A Banking Giant's Moral Bankruptcy on Iran
summary: HSBC's glib ad suggests that the Islamic Republic is hospitable to artists, especially women.

headline: From Parking Lot to Castle
summary: In downtown Albuquerque's "skid row" stands a very unlikely Paris-inspired estate.

headline: Groupon Raises $500 Million
summary: Closely held Groupon has raised $500 million of a nearly $1 billion round of new funding, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Bah Humbug of a Year
summary: George Steinbrenner and Bob Sheppard passed away and the Yankees fell two games short of returning to the World Series in a year marked by loss.

headline: Comptroller Voices Global Ambitions
summary: City Comptroller John Liu, who this year became the first Asian American to hold citywide elected office, admits to some lofty ambitions: Beyond merely wanting to become mayor, he'd aspire to the White House if the Constitution allowed.

headline: A New Look at Portugal's Past
summary: The Museu do Oriente in Lisbon allows visitors to re-examine a key aspect of the world's first truly global empire which reached a bloody end in the 1970s.

headline: Fiat Split Creates New Options
summary: When Fiat spins off its truck and tractor divisions, its cars and vans will be the riskier bet for investors but could offer greater potential to grow in value.

headline: Rattner Settles New York Scandal  For $10 Million
summary: Former Obama "car czar" Steven Rattner accepted a five-year ban on pension-fund business in New York and will pay $10 million under a deal with Andrew Cuomo.

headline: Europe 4, Jihadists 0
summary: When it comes to security, no government is better than its last victory.

headline: Clearwire Chairman McCaw to Resign
summary: Craig McCaw is resigning as chairman of Clearwire, the company he founded to roll out the first nationwide U.S. wireless broadband network.

headline: Free Trade, Drugs and India
summary: Attacking the means of funding pharmaceutical breakthroughs is a strange way to pursue global health.

headline: NFL Fines Jets Over Tripping Incident
summary: The NFL fined the Jets $100,000 as a result of the conduct of strength and conditioning coach Sal Alosi, who tripped an opposing player during the Jets' loss to the Miami Dolphins on Dec. 12.

headline: A Maverick Mutual-Fund Firm Is No. 1
summary: A mutual-fund company from Toronto that started offering funds to U.S. investors last year has promptly won the crown for having the best-performing stock fund and best fund of any kind for 2010.

headline: Flight Check-In Will Be Easier
summary: It should soon be easier to check in for flights and make connections, following the world-wide introduction by the International Air Transport Association of 2D bar-coded boarding passes.

headline: Vatican Creates Financial Watchdog
summary: The Vatican has created a new watchdog to supervise financial transactions and new laws against financial crimes.

headline: Delays Lead to Quantity Time
summary: The Great Christmas Storm of 2010 upended travel plans and left families with far more family time than they had anticipated.
